entry.title: I read halfway though this article and literally couldn't believe what I was reading... amazing!
entry.content:
As Voltaire once said “The secret of being a bore is to tell everything,” and the secret to a good story is to get the listener to care about the exposition before you reveal the conclusion. Many of the videos that go viral online are professionally produced pieces that fool the viewers into sharing the video with friends without realising that it’s an ad. Recently millions of people shared an artsy black and white video where actors pretended to kiss people for the first time, which was really an ad for a boring clothing company.

Last year Saatchi came up with this piece of slo-mo genius:

First Taste
Tasty video bit at #TEDxSydney 2013. Video by Saatchi & Heckler

Ads that go viral commonly focus on universal human truths that work in any language, on any continent. Many of the popular “best of web” videos focus on stunning nature scenes, slo-mo extreme sports and people with weird dance moves.

The parodies of the first kiss video are many and varied, this one with dogs is one of the stranger ones:

FIRST SNIFF (First Kiss Parody)
We asked some dogs to kiss for the first time…

Vice created a more realistically awkward video by getting 20 strangers who aren’t models to kiss each other. As Vice notes, a growing number of websites are getting better at tweaking algorithms to pump traffic-magnet content like “Half Way Through These Photos, I Could Barely Handle It. But I’m Glad I Made It to the End… Amazing.” As each new meme website tries to game social algorithms by running other people’s content under misleading headlines, more and more stories are just beat-ups created for the online outrage factory. One of the most egregious examples of race baiting is the bogus story that Chinese people are grinding up babies into soup to increase their sexual potency. In the race to reach the lowest common denominator, no barrier is too low for a quick buck.

Sometimes people make honest mistakes by repeating accidental misquotes, and indeed one of the most famous Voltaire quotes wasn’t his. Others are trying to make money using the internet to peddle bunk that’s been around for centuries:

Derren Brown - Science Of Scams | Brick Breaking
Derren Brown shows us a paranormal trick. SUBSCRIBE. AND LIKE

entry.title: Tech in Education - Khan Academy to offer SAT prep
entry.content:
The New York Times has some interesting coverage of recent developments in Ed-Tech. One of the big ones is that the US’s SAT system is going to partner with Khan Academy to deliver a classroom-focussed college admissions system, and provide preparation to everyone, rather than just the rich that can afford test prep classes. Free preparation for one of the most important US college admissions tests is a major coup for the organisation that Bill Gates and others have backed to improve the learning quality of students around the world.

Related news:

New All-Digital Curriculums Hope to Ride High-Tech Push in Schoolrooms

English language curriculums built entirely on a digital platform — replacing written textbooks, worksheets or printed study guides — are about to enter the market from several companies, with promises that they will change the nature of classroom learning across the country.

The Obama administration has pledged to provide high-speed Internet connections to 15,000 schools over the next two years, districts are purchasing tablets and laptops for students, and on Friday, President Obama announced $400 million in corporate commitments from the software companies Adobe and Prezi, which will donate software to teachers. Meanwhile, other companies are rushing in.

On Monday at an education conference in Austin, Tex., Joel Klein, the former chancellor of New York City public schools and the current chief executive of Amplify, the education unit of Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation, will introduce a digital English language arts curriculum for middle school.

Mr. Klein said the new software, which will run on a variety of devices and is priced at $45 per student a year, includes videos, games and vocabulary apps and allows teachers to track student writing and give feedback directly online. “This is not a bunch of souped-up PDFs,” Mr. Klein said, referring to digital versions of print documents.

McGraw Hill, the textbook publisher, will also announce this week that it has signed a partnership with StudySync, a company that creates digital English curriculum tools that have been deployed in 22,000 classrooms and are priced at about a third of Amplify’s rate.

No Child Left Untableted

The key, he said, is personalized learning — breaking free of the mass-production model, tailoring the curriculum to the student and redesigning it around proven competence rather than accrued face time, so that each student can go at his own pace. “Now your job is not to dispense knowledge,” Britt told the trainees. “It’s to facilitate learning. No longer is the teacher the bottleneck between students and knowledge. Rather, the teacher architects the environment — in the classroom, on the tablet, online, everywhere.”

Textbook efficiency:

When I asked Arne Duncan, the U. S. secretary of education, about the increasing amounts of money being spent by school systems on educational technology, he said: “We spend precious taxpayer money now on textbooks, buses, milk, all kinds of things. The real question is, ‘How do you spend more effectively?’ ” Electronic readers could make textbooks better and cheaper, he said. “As a country we spend $7 billion to $8 billion a year on textbooks. My simple question is, ‘Why?’ ” Referring to the six-year textbook-adoption cycle some states still use, Duncan said, “That’s a Neanderthal system.”

GigaOm has a good take on the design of Khan Academy

Since its founding in 2008 by former hedge fund analyst Salman Khan — who was making math videos in his spare time to tutor his cousins — Khan Academy has emerged as a new way to learn; one that is self paced, approachable, conversational and tries to help students master individual subjects before moving onto the next. Bill Gates is a big fan, as is Google and its chairman Eric Schmidt as well as Netflix CEO Reed Hastings — all of these big names invested in the company.

While millions of users access the site and watch its content, 30,000 classrooms also use the videos for in-school teaching and teachers (they call them coaches) can also use the software to track student progress. All of these moving parts are tied together by an understated design ethos that highlights simplicity, puts the content first, and tries remove frustration and friction from learning.

Audrey Watters has a good roundup of the politics of the “Open” label being applied beyond open source tech, especially in Ed-Tech where “open” online courses more commonly means ”open for business”. She has an extensive discussion of MOOC hype in a 2013 rundown that is well worth a read.

entry.title: Sir David Attenborough: Enough With the Creationists and Climate Change Deniers
entry.content:
Great article in The Daily Beast:

Sir David Attenborough is one of the great naturalists of our time, celebrated for decades of peerless documentary making, an infectious love of the animal kingdom and that distinctive and enthusiastic whisper. Once criticized by campaigners for his reticence to address contentious issues, Attenborough is no longer willing to speak in hushed tones.

Sitting opposite the kangaroo enclosure at London Zoo, he told The Daily Beast he had lost patience with the “ignorance” of creationists, polluters, and climate change deniers. “To simply say that you must accept unquestioningly what you learned at your mother’s knee is not the act of an intelligent person,” he said.

He vents his frustration with religious zealots

Every society in the world has found it necessary to produce a story to account for the fact that humanity is on earth,” he said. “The Australian Aboriginals think that the first humans were regurgitated by a great rainbow serpent in the sky, the people in Thailand think the beginning of the world was a huge pool of milk and a snake was pulled by demons, and the milk coagulated and that formed human beings and there was a time, two and a half to three thousand years ago, when people on the east end of the Mediterranean thought woman was made from the rib of the first man.

“If somebody says to me I believe every word of the Bible is true, you can’t argue against that degree of irrationality…there is actually a way of looking at the natural world and seeing the evidence and it’s all there. And what’s more it’s the same evidence whether it’s in Australia or Northern Europe or wherever. It’s all the same—it all produces the same answer and you can all see the evidence—if you reject that then there’s nothing I can say.”

Many atheists and scientists opposed the debate, as they were concerned it would legitimise pseudoscience as worthy of scientific consideration, and give money to Ham to build his full scale “replica” of the ark. After the event most commentators decided that Ham shot himself in the foot by relying on the bible, but admitting that his beliefs will never change:

Ken Ham Defeats Himself In 90 Seconds
Did you guys see the debate between Bill Nye VS Ken Ham? Bill Nye did not even need to show up because Ken Ham was nice enough to totally defeat himself in humiliating fashion. If you enjoy my work. Slate notes that HBO is airing a documentary about the rise of creationism in America, with the following quote from a pastor:

“If somewhere in the Bible I were to find a passage that says two plus two equals five,” the pastor states plainly, “I wouldn’t question what I’m reading in the Bible. I would believe it—accept it as true and then do my best to work it out and to understand it.”

The problem is that the bible asks belivers to think that pi is 3 in 1 Kings:

And he made a molten sea, ten cubits from the one brim to the other: it was round all about, and his height was five cubits: and a line of thirty cubits did compass it round about.

Biblical literalists have a range of bogus explanations for why these numbers are true, without embracing the idea that mathematics is wrong. We don’t call someone a theistic mathematician if they believe in the accuracy of pi, or a theistic meteorologist if they believe rain comes from clouds rather than storehouses in heaven. The mythical beasts that were included in the King James Bible, like Satyrs, Unicorns and Cockatrices have mostly been retranslated in modern bibles. It was said in relation to the Nephilim that ”There’s a sucker born every minute” and most people find the mythical creatures laughable:

Other than the occasional hick, nobody challenges the heliocentric model, and the flat earth society seems to have fallen over the edge of the disc. Other than Phil Plait, nobody decries the spherist bias in the media. Evolution is one of the only areas where children are encouraged to disrupt their science classes, and United States legislatures are trying to encourage the teaching of nonsense. Creationists have managed to get hundreds of millions of dollars in federal funding in Australia to persue their secterian agenda, and are set to introduce creationism as an “alternate perspective” into the history curriculum during the national curriculum review.

Bill Nye’s biggest appeal in his debate was that for Western countries to be globally competitive in the 21st century, we need to empower science educators to give children a love of learning that will prepare them to be innovators in the rapidly changing technology sector. Religiously and politically motivated campaigns instead want to cast doubt about scientific consensus on topics like evolution and climate change, and are well financed to do so. Anyone with a love of science needs to fight the underhanded campaigns that are trying undermine science education in school classrooms.

entry.title: Youth Perspectives on Tech in Schools: From Mobile Devices to Restrictions and Monitoring
entry.content:
Interesting report on SSRN on the use of tech in schoos, and the youth perspectives on network restrictions and monitoring. Students expressed frustration at the top down focus on technology; “while many participants reported positive feelings around the current state of technology in their schools, some students seemed frustrated about ongoing initiatives to provide them with tablets for academic purposes. Several participants stated that they would have preferred new laptops to new tablets.” Some students expressed frustration at inequalities between the ICT resources of different schools.

78% of young people now have a cell phone, and almost half (47%) of those own smartphones. A large number of students refuse to hand in their devices, even though they don’t plan to use them in school hours. A number of students felt frustrated at the disconnect between ICT policy and the concept of the school trusting their students. Some students use Wifi networks from neighbouring buildings because of speed constraints, and blocking of websites that have information on news topics like rapes in India. The schools need to follow Children’s Internet Protection Act (CIPA) guidelines, which don’t include the blocking of social media sites, even though most schools include it. More public schools than private schools block sites like youtube, which has both “distracting” and objectionable content, as well as educational content. Some students found that blocking Facebook blocked educational sites like Khan Academy that use OAuth to login. Students that saved homework on personal email accounts weren’t able to access them from some school networks.

37% of students admit to bypassing filtering themselves, with simple workarounds like SSL/TLS sites allowed. Some students use VPNs on their own devices. Blocking encrypted tunneling is beyond most school ICT administrators, and there’s a growing recognition that censorship in institutions like public libraries is ineffective and curtails free speech. In a telling statement, one student reveals that teachers sometimes ask their students how to bypass filters.

One of the most problematic issues in the paper is the privacy issue. Schools have legitimate reasons to use screen sharing tools to prevent disruptive behaviour, but this also gives teachers mostly unaccountable access to record private student communications. Most of the privacy protections are in school policy, rather than in the technology itself.

Students have a range of legitimate reasons to bypass censorship, and legitimate concerns around their own privacy. Schools have opened up as a new front in the classic war of users vs owners. The shift from from centrally controlled mainframes to user centric PC’s brought a raft of security issues before some smartphone and tablet vendors moved to a walled garden approach.

ITU figures show that mobile broadband subscriptions are one of the fastest growing sectors in telecomms:

It seems like the only way to be sure that your kid is getting the full educational benefit of the internet without being monitored is to buy them a mobile broadband subscription and send them to a private school. And then ask yourself why on earth we have a digital divide.

entry.title: Curiosity's Pale Blue Dot
entry.content:
The curiosity rover has shot an image of the sky in mars, with Earth appearing as a tiny speck of light

When you hear about four year olds vowing to slaughter their enemies in a war that has claimed the lives of 10,000 children think about how great the bloodshed is over control of such a tiny fraction of such a small planet. Shane Smith notes that at the same time as people are looking at the surface of mars on their smartphones, uneducated Afghan boys are being used in suicide attacks against civilians on Muslim holy days.

It brings to mind one of Carl Sagan’s most famous speeches:

“Look again at that dot. That’s here. That’s home. That’s us. On it everyone you love, everyone you know, everyone you ever heard of, every human being who ever was, lived out their lives. The aggregate of our joy and suffering, thousands of confident religions, ideologies, and economic doctrines, every hunter and forager, every hero and coward, every creator and destroyer of civilization, every king and peasant, every young couple in love, every mother and father, hopeful child, inventor and explorer, every teacher of morals, every corrupt politician, every “superstar,” every “supreme leader,” every saint and sinner in the history of our species lived there-on a mote of dust suspended in a sunbeam.

The Earth is a very small stage in a vast cosmic arena. Think of the endless cruelties visited by the inhabitants of one corner of this pixel on the scarcely distinguishable inhabitants of some other corner, how frequent their misunderstandings, how eager they are to kill one another, how fervent their hatreds. Think of the rivers of blood spilled by all those generals and emperors so that, in glory and triumph, they could become the momentary masters of a fraction of a dot.

Our posturings, our imagined self-importance, the delusion that we have some privileged position in the Universe, are challenged by this point of pale light. Our planet is a lonely speck in the great enveloping cosmic dark. In our obscurity, in all this vastness, there is no hint that help will come from elsewhere to save us from ourselves.

The Earth is the only world known so far to harbor life. There is nowhere else, at least in the near future, to which our species could migrate. Visit, yes. Settle, not yet. Like it or not, for the moment the Earth is where we make our stand.

It has been said that astronomy is a humbling and character-building experience. There is perhaps no better demonstration of the folly of human conceits than this distant image of our tiny world. To me, it underscores our responsibility to deal more kindly with one another, and to preserve and cherish the pale blue dot, the only home we’ve ever known.”

entry.title: Can we Know Anything?
entry.content:
Consider this: your colleague David has been running late to work and needs to buy a new alarm clock. He goes to a clock shop with 100 clocks to find one to buy, but upon inspecting the clocks, he finds that some disagree with each other. About 3% of the clocks have a major discrepancy with the other clocks. Which is a reasonable conclusion?

  1. David decides to buy a clock, and trusts that it can tell the time accurately enough
  2. David decides to go to another shop that will have better clocks
  3. David decides not to buy a clock, not trusting the accuracy of any clocks he could buy
  4. David confirms his suspicion that time cannot be measured by anyone (which he had deduced from his study of ancient poetry that describe the gods as making time as a stream that ebbs and flows), and laments the number of poor children duped by the pro-temporalist bias in the media and the public schooling system, that have conspired to push dissenting voices out of the public sphere because of corporate interests and the academic pride of liberal elites in their ivory towers at so-called ivy league universities.

I think we all understand that 4 is not a reasonable position, but sophists have for centuries tried to confuse the public by describing scientific uncertainty and scientific doubt as the same thing. I mention the example of clocks because Bill Nye used it as an example of scientific uncertainty in his debate with the young earth creationist Ken Ham. Ham claims that discrepancies between certain forms of radiometric dating mean that nobody can have any trust that the earth is more than 10,000 years old, which is his a priori conclusion derived from selective interpretation of a modern translation of an ancient Hebrew religious text. Nye’s example is a good one, because nobody objects to the conclusion that time is measurable, and so nobody tries to use the tricks that creationists and flat-earthers will use when discussing science.

In 1864 the founder of the Flat Earth Society, Dr Parallax, was finally challenged to perform a public experiment to test his claim of a flat earth. An astronomer predicted that because of the curvature of the earth, only the lantern of a distant lighthouse would be visible. The effect of the curvature of the earth was greater than what the astronomer had predicted, and Parallax observed only half the lantern of the lighthouse, leading him to claim that he won the experiment. The example of Parallax shows the clear danger of an uncharismatic scientist unable to cope with a charlatan.

It’s very easy to spin certain soundbites in a way that a scientifically illiterate audience won’t understand. Consider, for instance, the cooling periods that can be found by cherry picking the regions of analysis in global temperatures:

Scientists need to be careful in a world of soundbites that they aren’t completely misrepretented by charlatans. As Carl Sagan said “if we are not able to ask skeptical questions, to interrogate those who tell us that something is true, to be skeptical of those in authority, then we’re up for grabs, for the next charlatan, political or religious who comes ambling along.” Unfortunately, with weak scientific education and a media that present false balance, it can be hard for sicentists to demonstrate the consensus they have on issues. On climate issues, NASA and the NOAA are putting more effort into publishing information themselves.

entry.title: Scott Morrison's Moral Barometer
entry.content:
Dr Marrion Maddox spoke about the rise of Christian fundamentalism in Australian politics in 2006:

Christian parties have existed in Australia for a long time, but, due to the robust two- party system, have seldom had much direct electoral influence18. The Christian Democratic Party (CDP) and its predecessor (Call to Australia) have been represented in the New South Wales upper house since 1981, but enjoyed their sole, fleeting federal presence for a few months in 1998.

The big news story of the 2004 federal election was the national launch of Adelaide- based minor party Family First (FFP). With one member already in the South Australian upper house, FFP ran federal candidates all over Australia. Despite a small primary vote, elaborate preference deals meant that the party had one Senator elected, Victorian Steve Fielding. Most of the candidates were members of one denomination, the Assemblies of God. Others, such as Fielding, came from related Pentecostal traditions. A few identified with other traditions, such as Catholic. Despite these connections, the party emphatically portrayed itself as a ‘family values’ party, rejecting suggestions that it is a ‘Christian party’. Party events sometimes resemble church functions, and vice versa20, but the party’s website scrupulously avoids religious references, leading even other Christian parties to allege duplicity on FFP’s part21. The media image of FFP as a Christian party has persisted, despite official denials. For example, on the Sunday morning after the election, when it appeared FFP might have the balance of power in the Senate, veteran television journalist Laurie Oakes proposed that FFP’s success marked ‘the arrival of the religious right in Australian politics’.

However, despite the huge media fascination it generated, FFP was only ever a sideshow in Australian religious right politics. Far more significant was the positioning of the Liberal Party increasingly towards the religious right, which, as I document in detail in my book God Under Howard: The Rise of the Religious Right in Australian Politics23 , had been underway since the formation of the federal Liberal Party’s socially conservative, ambiguously-Christian Lyons Forum pressure group in the early 1990s. Religious priming (known journalistically as the ‘dog-whistle’ strategy) reached its peak in the lead-up to the 2004 campaign.

Here, too, the Assemblies of God featured prominently. While Adelaide’s Paradise Church was the launching pad for FFP, its Sydney counterpart, Hillsong, became associated with the Liberal Party. Not only did John Howard, his Liberal deputy Peter Costello and other senior Liberals address the church, but Hillsong has claimed Liberal Member for Mitchell Alan Cadman, Young Liberals president Alex Hawke and former NSW Liberal Party director Scott Morrison as members.

Nick Bryant notes that Morrison was mentored by Brian Houston himself, which is where he bases his ethical foundation:

Morrison is now a Pentecostal and thus part of the most rapidly growing denomination in the land. He worships at an American-style mega-church called Shirelive in his constituency, where the gospel of prosperity is preached in an auditorium that can accommodate over 1000 evangelicals. With its water baptisms and designer-shirt pastors, Shirelive has close ties with the better-known Hillsong community. The founder of Hillsong, Harley Davidson–riding pastor Brian Houston, is one of Morrison’s mentors. In Who’s Who Morrison lists the church as his number one hobby, and his maiden speech reads in part like a personal testimony delivered on the last night of a church retreat. It included passages from Jeremiah and also the Book of Joel: “Your old men will dream dreams, your young men will see visions.”

A test of his faith came during the period when he and his wife were trying to start a family. It involved repeated courses of IVF treatment and “14 years of bitter disappointments”, but Scott and Jenny were buoyed by their sense of the providential. “God remembered her faithfulness,” recalled Morrison during his maiden speech, as he paid tribute to his wife, “and blessed us with our miracle child, Abbey Rose.” The couple now have two daughters.

While his faith animates his politics, he is on the record as saying “the Bible is not a policy handbook, and I get very worried when people try to treat it like one”. Critics would say that is self-evident from his heartless response to asylum seekers. “I wonder how you can claim to be a serious Christian and take these positions,” said one former colleague. Supporters, however, claim he has pursued a faith-based policy. “He’s a very ethical and moral man,” says a fellow Liberal. “Stopping the boats is ethical and moral.” In his response to December’s boat people tragedy off Java, he advocated a ‘tough love’ policy, which he claimed had the safety of boat people at its heart. After all, for Morrison the Pacific Solution was not only efficient but righteous since it crushed the evil of people smuggling. Church friends might even have seen shades of Wilberforce in his efforts to eradicate such a nefarious trade. To his critics, however, his attacks on the government, which resumed 48 hours after the overloaded boat capsized, offered yet more proof of his harrying opportunism: this was more about political point-scoring than finding a workable solution.

entry.title: The Media Still Pushing Debunked Gerson Therapy
entry.content:
Jessica Ainscough is working though a list of patsies, finding her way into being reported (with the barest of skepticism) by the Sydney Morning Herald. I wrote about her unfortunate dependance on quackery in June, and her mother has since passed away. Orac notes that as Ainscough’s mother was dying, she claimed that the tumours were “healing reactions” and there was an underlying “copper toxicity” supposedly treatable with chelation therapy:

How many times have we heard cancer quacks say this, that the cancer is not the problem but rather a “symptom” of the “real” problem or a “protective reaction” to the real problem?

As I noted in June, Ainscough invented “psychic pollution”

our negative thoughts also contribute to pollution on our planet. This is called ‘psychic pollution.’ This fact has been proven: what we think and feel has a direct impact on the world around us

There are many benefits to encouraging cancer patients to seek professional counselling services when dealing with the side effects of radiation and chemotherapy, as well as depression resulting from their diagnosis. Unfortunately, many quacks try to adopt the language of pop-psychology and tell people with terminal cancer that their depression is the cause of their terminal condition, and they need to force themselves to think positively in order to be cured. Not only will terminal patients go to the grabe believing that they have some spiritual or mental deficiency that causes their condition, but quacks are given an easy excuse for the failures of treatments on patients believed to be too “weak” or “faithless”.

entry.title: Media Manipulation
entry.content:
Following the shooting of Gabrielle Giffords, a large number of left leaning media outlets criticised the right wing media’s hype and extremism. Dan Lyons took them to task:

The problem began when news became tied to profits. The networks at one time used to run news as a loss leader, subsidized by entertainment. When that changed, and news started chasing ratings (and dollars), the problem began. When dollars started to dry up, things only got worse. Networks became desperate and resorted to making the news more like entertainment.

The Internet made things worse, in two ways. First, the Internet exacerbated the decline in revenues, and heightened the desperation in the news business. Trust me, I’m in a position to know, because I’m in the business of seeing just how far I can make news people bend in order to keep getting my advertising dollars. That influence is stronger now than it has ever been. The TV networks and magazines and newspapers are desperate and terrified. Stuff that 10 years ago they would have thrown back in our face they now do willingly — in fact, they don’t even wait for us to suggest it. They suggest it themselves.

But second, and more important, the Internet created an outlet for competing and often crazy voices. It gave birth to a new kind of “news.” Despite what the new-media pundits claim, the much-celebrated “citizen journalism” was all too often just noisy crap and propaganda.

Most of the news is written by interns that only get hired if they drive enough clicks to their linkbait articles:

It’s garbage precisely because online news sites are not primarily created to report news. They’re created to make money. Problem is, it’s nearly impossible to make money doing what they do. So they resort to ever more desperate tricks.

Why is so much online “news” reported in slideshow format? To gin up clicks. Not because it is a better way to consume news, because, please. Why is HuffPo so crowded with sensationalistic tabloid junk about celebrity boobs and fluffy “lists” of “the deadliest ice creams.” (And just about everyone else, too. )

Ryan Holiday gave a keynote at TNW about how bad glorified blog journalism is, and how easy it is to exploit media into running “controversial” linkbait stories, like Sasha Grey in an American Apparel ad campaign.

entry.title: Tecnoutopianism
entry.content:
I was going to write a post on Ivy League universities backing Massive Open Online Courses though edX and other providers, and started thinking back to the discussion of the OLPC project in 2007. Widespread media coverage showed Kofi Annan holding a prototype laptop with a hand crank and repeated the claim that the device would eventually be available for $100. The hand crank and the $100 price tag were unachievable, and major glitches in the first version of the laptops dampened the hype surrounding the project.

Vaclav Smil, professor emeritus of environment and geography at the University of Manitoba commented on the media’s tendency to see technology as a magic solution to intractable problems:

So the answers are not technological but political: better economic policies, better education, better trade policies.

Right. Today, as you know, everything is “innovation.” We have problems, and people are looking for fairy-tale solutions—innovation like manna from heaven falling on the Israelites and saving them from the desert. It’s like, “Let’s not reform the education system, the tax system. Let’s not improve our dysfunctional government. Just wait for this innovation manna from a little group of people in Silicon Valley, preferably of Indian origin.”

You people at WIRED—you’re the guilty ones! You support these people, you write about them, you elevate them onto the cover! You really messed it up. I tell you, you pushed this on the American public, right? And people believe it now.

Smil notes that the idea of efficiency gains in every sector is “Moore’s curse”

You call this Moore’s curse—the idea that if we’re innovative enough, everything can have yearly efficiency gains.

It’s a categorical mistake. You just cannot increase the efficiency of power plants like that. You have your combustion machines—the best one in the lab now is about 40 percent efficient. In the field they’re about 15 or 20 percent efficient. Well, you can’t quintuple it, because that would be 100 percent efficient. Impossible, right? There are limits. It’s not a microchip.

The same thing is true in agriculture. You cannot increase the efficiency of photosynthesis. We improve the performance of farms by irrigating them and fertilizing them to provide all these nutrients. But we cannot keep on doubling the yield every two years. Moore’s law doesn’t apply to plants.

Benjamin Bratton made similar talks in a TEDx talk about technological utopianism overlooking the difficult problems in philosophy and economics:

The key rhetorical device for TED talks is a combination of epiphany and personal testimony (an “epiphimony” if you like ) through which the speaker shares a personal journey of insight and realisation, its triumphs and tribulations.

What is it that the TED audience hopes to get from this? A vicarious insight, a fleeting moment of wonder, an inkling that maybe it’s all going to work out after all? A spiritual buzz?

I’m sorry but this fails to meet the challenges that we are supposedly here to confront. These are complicated and difficult and are not given to tidy just-so solutions. They don’t care about anyone’s experience of optimism. Given the stakes, making our best and brightest waste their time – and the audience’s time – dancing like infomercial hosts is too high a price. It is cynical.

Also, it just doesn’t work.

Recently there was a bit of a dust up when TEDGlobal sent out a note to TEDx organisers asking them not to not book speakers whose work spans the paranormal, the conspiratorial, new age “quantum neuroenergy”, etc: what is called woo. Instead of these placebos, TEDx should instead curate talks that are imaginative but grounded in reality. In fairness, they took some heat, so their gesture should be acknowledged. A lot of people take TED very seriously, and might lend credence to specious ideas if stamped with TED credentials. “No” to placebo science and medicine.

But … the corollaries of placebo science and placebo medicine are placebo politics and placebo innovation. On this point, TED has a long way to go.

Perhaps the pinnacle of placebo politics and innovation was featured at TEDx San Diego in 2011. You’re familiar I assume with Kony2012, the social media campaign to stop war crimes in central Africa? So what happened here? Evangelical surfer bro goes to help kids in Africa. He makes a campy video explaining genocide to the cast of Glee. The world finds his public epiphany to be shallow to the point of self-delusion. The complex geopolitics of central Africa are left undisturbed. Kony’s still there. The end.

You see, when inspiration becomes manipulation, inspiration becomes obfuscation. If you are not cynical you should be sceptical. You should be as sceptical of placebo politics as you are placebo medicine.

entry.title: New Map Shows the Harm of the Anti-Vaccine Movement
entry.content:
A new map by the Council on Foreign Relations shows the rising number of vaccine preventable diseases in first world contries. After Andrew Wakefield took out a patent on a single Measels vaccine he falsified a study that appeared to show that appeared to show that the Measels, Mumps and Rubella triple antigen was unsafe for children, proposing his own patented vaccine as a “safer” alternative. Even after Wakefield’s paper has been retracted for innacuracy, and he was struck off the medical register for “dishonest”, “unethical” and “callous” behaviour, anti-vaccine hysteria continues to spread thoughout the world. The drop in MMR vaccination rates in Wales to below 80% has caused a widespread measels outbreak, leaving parents of infected teenagers feeling betrayed by the lies of the anti-vaccine movement:

Wakefield MMR fraud comes home to roost in Wales
Australian ABC Lateline programme looks at the early-2013 outbreak of measles in Wales UK. A recent measles fatality is likely linked to the Andrew Wakefield MMR fraud which led to a baseless reduction in uptake of the MMR vaccine. It’s apparent that now fear of the demonstrable harm of measles outweighs the fallacious fear of MMR. Notifications equal 800 since November 2012 - approximately 7 times that for the entire year of 2012. The vast majority of parents now accept that the “callous” and deregistered Wakefield is a charlatan and a fraud.

A recent measles fatality is likely linked to the Andrew Wakefield MMR fraud which led to a baseless reduction in uptake of the MMR vaccine. It’s apparent that now fear of the demonstrable harm of measles outweighs the fallacious fear of MMR. Notifications equal 800 since November 2012 - approximately 7 times that for the entire year of 2012. The vast majority of parents now accept that the “callous” and deregistered Wakefield is a charlatan and a fraud.

Interestingly, Wakefield is only the latest in a long line of cranks opposed to the vaccination of children. I recently came across a talk by Professor Gareth Williams on the history of the anti-vaccine movement, going right back to Jenner himself. Some doctors opposed cowpox vaccination as smallpox cases were a large portion of their business, but most interestingly many people found religious arguments against vaccination. Theologians in France and England argued that ”diseases are sent by Providence for the punishment of sin” and suggested that Job’s boils and ulcers were a result of cowpox vaccination by Satan. One of the most wacko opponents of the Jennerian society wrote that smallpox helped to lower the size of poor families:

why is it not remembered that in the populous parts of the Metropolis, where the abundance of children exceed the means of providing food, and raiment for them, this pestilential disease is considered as a merciful provision on the part of Providence, to lessen the burthen of a poor man’s family ?

Interestingly, while most doctors (Wakefield excluded) would never seek to harm their patients to increase their own business, many pastors coninue to teach that children should not be vaccinated against infectious diseases. Measels outbreaks have been observed in areas with low vaccination rates, commonly correlated with high numbers of evangelical megachurches. Unfortunately, a number of churches order their congregation to eschew medical treatment in favour of prayer, which Republican lawmakers protect as “religious freedom”, even after a spate of preventable deaths.

entry.title: Pia Waugh on Technology's new Citizinship at TEDx
entry.content:
Pia Waugh is the former president of Linux Australia, and she gave a great talk at a TEDx event in Canberra:

The new citizenship: Pia Waugh at TEDxCanberraWomen
Pia Waugh is an open government and open data advocate, working to enable greater transparency, democratic engagement, citizen-centric design, and pragmatic innovation in the public sector and beyond. She believes that tech culture has a huge role to play in achieving better policy planning, outcomes, public engagement and a better public service. In the spirit of ideas worth spreading, TEDx is a program of local, self-organized events that bring people together to share a TED-like experience. At a TEDx event, TEDTalks video and live speakers combine to spark deep discussion and connection in a small group. These local, self-organized events are branded TEDx, where x = independently organized TED event. The TED Conference provides general guidance for the TEDx program, but individual TEDx events are self-organized.* (*Subject to certain rules and regulations)

A few great points * Inverting William Gibson’s view: “The future is here, and it is widely distributed” * There is a global shift in power from the West to the East, and from traditional centralised power structures to users. * The ability to see different perspectives over the same medium challenges the idea of a single source of truth. * The freedom of the users comes directly from the freedom of the tools they use. * Technologists have the abilitiy to route around a damaged system, but they have a moral responsibility to represent those that can’t. * Internet users are among only a third of the world, and so every internet user has the power to effect the world in positive ways. * Pia on Hipsters: Billie Brag quote “Cynicism is the perfect enemy of progress.” * If we don’t work to shape the future, someone else is going to shape it for us. * The future is not just being determned in traditional ways.

New technologies often evoke rumors of hazard. These generally fade with time when, as in this case, no real hazards emerge.
